title: Quarto for managers
text:
üë©‚Äçüíª Your turn: New report

Open binder   
File ‚û°Ô∏è New File ‚û°Ô∏è Quarto Document
Enter Title & Author
Leave HTML selected
Click Create
Click Render Document (you‚Äôll be prompted to save first)
Try changing some text and then re-rendering with Render Document

title: Quarto for managers
text: üëÄ Demo: Simple plot and text

title: Quarto for managers
text:
üë©‚Äçüíª Your turn: New report

Open binder   
Open exercise-2/simple.qmd
Click Render
Change blue to red and re-render
Change the filter to > 2024-12-31 and re-render

title: Quarto for managers
text: Example report

title: Quarto for managers
text:
Template based-reports

---
title:"NHS Workforce Statistics for `r params$ics_name`"
subtitle:"Data for `r params$month_year`"
author:"Maria Garcia"
date:"2023-09-28"
params:
  ics_name:"North East and North Cumbria"
  month_year:"April 2023"
---

title: Quarto for managers
text:
Read in the data

  filename
= glue(
  "NHS Workforce Statistics, {params$month_year} England and Organisation.xlsx"
)

title: Quarto for managers
text:
Clean the data

staff_group =
  staff_group |>
  filter(`ICS name` == params$ics_name) |>
  select(
    `Organisation name`,
    `Total`,
    `HCHS Doctors`,
    `Nurses & health visitors`,
    `Midwives`,
    `Ambulance staff`
  )

title: Quarto for managers
text:
Add insight

The table below shows the total number of doctors and nurses for each organisation within `r params$ics_name`. We can see that the organisation with the most midwives is the `r pull(max_midwives, "Organisation name")` with `r round(max_midwives$Midwives)` staff.

title: Quarto for managers
text:
Re-run next month

---
title: "NHS Workforce Statistics for `r params$ics_name`"
subtitle: "Data for `r params$month_year`"
author: "Maria Garcia"
date: "2023-09-28"
params:
  ics_name: "North East and North Cumbria"
  month_year: "May 2023"

title: Quarto for managers
text:
Report a different region

---
title: "NHS Workforce Statistics for `r params$ics_name`"
subtitle: "Data for `r params$month_year`"
author: "Maria Garcia"
date: "2023-09-28"
params:
  ics_name: "Lancashire and South Cumbria"
  month_year: "May 2023"

title: Quarto for managers
text:
üë©‚Äçüíª Your turn: Parameters

Open binder   
Open exercise-3/example-report.qmd
Change month_year: July 2025 to June 2025 and re-render
Change ics_name: "North East and North Cumbria" to another ICS

title: Quarto for managers
text:
Maria is happy



More reproducible workflow
Fewer mistakes
Spends less time formatting the reports manually
Spends more time adding insight

title: üë©‚Äçüíª Set up
text:
You do not need anything install on your computer to take part in this workshop.
There are some interactive sections which can completed in binder.
  
You may need to wait a few moments for it to load. There are two exercise folders with quarto files for you to try editing and rendering.
Thanks to the Binder project and {holepunch} package. My set-up files for binder are on GitHub.

title: üë©‚Äçüè´ Slides
text: üîç View full-size

title: üëã Welcome
text:
Meet Maria, a public health analyst who produces monthly NHS workforce reports. She crunches data in Excel, writes reports in Word, and spends hours formatting tables and charts. When the data changes or her manager requests a new region, she has to start over again.
In this hands-on workshop, we‚Äôll show how Quarto and parameterised, template-based reporting can transform workflows like Maria‚Äôs. Participants will see how analysts can interweave text and code to produce reproducible, automated reports that are easier to update, reduce mistakes, and free up time for insight and decision-making.
Through a short practical exercise, managers will get a glimpse of the technology, see its benefits in action, and understand how investing in reproducible reporting can improve efficiency, consistency, and the impact of analytical work across health and care teams.

title: üëã Welcome
text:
Meet Maria, a public health analyst who produces monthly NHS workforce reports. She crunches data in Excel, writes reports in Word, and spends hours formatting tables and charts. When the data changes or her manager requests a new region, she has to start over again.
In this hands-on workshop, we‚Äôll show how Quarto and parameterised, template-based reporting can transform workflows like Maria‚Äôs. Participants will see how analysts can interweave text and code to produce reproducible, automated reports that are easier to update, reduce mistakes, and free up time for insight and decision-making.
Through a short practical exercise, managers will get a glimpse of the technology, see its benefits in action, and understand how investing in reproducible reporting can improve efficiency, consistency, and the impact of analytical work across health and care teams.

title: üëã Welcome
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of the session, attendees will

understand the benefits of Quarto
have an understanding of if Quarto could help their team
have built their own basic report

title: üëã Welcome
text:
Prerequisites
This workshop is aimed at managers. No prior coding or Quarto experience necessary at all.

title: ‚ùì FAQs
text: Coming soon! A few notes following questions we got at the workshop

title: ‚ùì FAQs
section: What are the pros and cons for .HTML files?
text: What are the pros and cons for .HTML files?

title: ‚ùì FAQs
section: How do I stop the code appearing in my reports
text:
How do I stop the code appearing in my reports
Set #| echo: false at the top of your code chunk

title: ‚ùì FAQs
section: How can I add alt text to my plots?
text:
How can I add alt text to my plots?
Use #| fig-alt="Informative alt text describing the plot" at the top of your code chunk

title: ‚ùì FAQs
section: If moving from RMkarkdown to Quarto - what are key differences to be aware of?
text: If moving from RMkarkdown to Quarto - what are key differences to be aware of?

title: ‚ùì FAQs
section: How can I brand my reports>
text:
How can I brand my reports>

brand.yml
